bibl.title: Letter from James Hildebrand to the American Association for Medical Progress, March 26, 1928

div1.p: Hildebrand requests a higher pension and describes his service with the yellow fever commission in Cuba. He also states that Reed trembled all over when an infected mosquito escaped. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from James Hildebrand to the American Association for Medical Progress, March 26, 1928
div1.opener:
COPY
Atlanta, Georgia,
March 26, 1928
American Association for Medical Progress
370 Seventh Avenue
New York City
Gentlemen:
div1.p:
I served with the yellow fever commission in Cuba under
Major Walter Reed. Dr Carroll was placing charged mosquitoes on
my naked back and Major Reed was in the enclosure with him and one
of the mosquitoes got away. It so shocked him that he shook all !!?
over and no doubt but caused his nervous breakdown and final death
at Washington D. C.

I served throughout with the commission until the mosqui-
toes was convicted of being the transmitter of yellow fever and
saved the government millions of dollars from destruction of prop-
erty by cinderation.

I was born Nov. 9, 1854. If I live I will soon be 74
years old. I am suffering from tuberlocis and I am unable to work.
I went before a medical board at Gainesville, Georgia and they gave
me a total disability as a Spanish War Veteran. I am drawing a pen-
sion of $50.00permonth. It takes part of it to pay my medicine bill
to keep me alive. I live with an old sister of mine, a widow older
than I am, on 412 Berean Avenue. She has no income and shares what
I have.

Two of my comrades in the same experimenting commission,
to wit, Kissinger and West, are getting $100.00 per month by an
act of Congress. It would help me very much if I could get the same.
div1.closer: Very respectfully, JAMES HILDEBRAND (Signed) Incl H I
